all_paragraphs: As a data scientist, it is convenient to know some basic useful command lines. You may have some favorite command-line commands that you keep using them over and over again.
For example, you want to create a Django app, a library that makes it easy to create a web app with Python. To set up the folder and environment for your Django app, you need to do the following:
Since we want to use the same command-line commands to create a new app in the future, would it be nice if we can save these commands somewhere then use it when we want to create a new app?
and every basic step to set up an app should be taken care of? This article will show you how to make your commands more reusable and fast to execute.
First, we start with creating a file with touch and use .sh for a shell script.
Use nano to edit the file
We should be able to insert all of our commands here
Close the file with Control + X (or Command + X with Mac). Type y for saving the change. Use Enter to get out of the file.
Now run the file with Bash
The app should be set up and ready to use! But why bash? Bash is the shell, or command language interpreter. Is there a way we can just run the file without bash? Try to run
What is going one here? Take a look at the permission of this file using
We will see something similar to this

If we look at the characters rw right after the first — , we can see that user who owns the file can read r and write w but cannot execute x. So we just need to add the permission to execute the file using
u stands for user, + stands for add permission, and x stands for executing. Now we should be able to run our file without bash!
We find this file so convenient that we decided to share with our friends or run it on another computer. We might need to be aware of the possible change in the environment.

The Bash shell, which is what we are using, is executed in this directory /bin/sh by default. Other shells may have different defaults. So to make sure that this file always works properly (when using in another computer), we should add this add the beginning of our createapp.sh file

We have succeeded in creating an app with bash file. But what if we want another name for our next app? We could either edit the file or use a faster approach, have the name as a variable in our script!
Replace newapp with a variable, which in this case APPNAME. Use $1 to indicate to take the first parameter when running the script. Replace every appname with $APPNAME.
And another app with a new name is created!
We have been successful in executing our app from the current directory. Wouldn’t it be even more convenient if we can execute this script from any directory on our computer?
To enable our file to run from everywhere, we will add this file to PATH, an environmental variable that tells the shell which directories to search for executable files.
Find a list of directories under PATH.
Pick one directory and move your file into that directory. Let’s say I choose /usr/local/bin to be the directory to save all my tools
That’s it! In the future, you can execute the script in any directory in your computer with
without the need to memorize every step.

Congratulation! You have learned how to make your command-line reusable. If you haven’t used this tool yet, you should consider adding this tool to your workflow. A little change in your workflow could add a huge amount of time back in the future.
